headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MONTANA, DR. JOHN B
summary: MONTANA--Dr. John B . AIDS specialist/Gay Activist, dies at 61. John Buscemi Montana, M.D., gay man, physician, generous humanitarian, New Yorker, world traveler and art aficionado, died at Mt. Sinai Hospital early Monday morning, September 29, 2008. The cause of death was acute myelogenous leukemia (AML), diagnosed less than one year ago. Dr. Montana was one of the first NYC physicians to identify and treat people with AIDS at the outset of the epidemic in 1981. He saw many cases among his friends and the gay men who comprised a large portion of his internal medicine practice on lower Fifth Avenue in Greenwich Village. Dr. Montana, the son of Vanni Buscemi Montana and Helen Bortnovski Montana, was born in Huntington, Long Island, NY on March 13, 1947. His parents met in Europe during World War II. John's father was politically active in anti-fascist and socialist causes in his native Sicily; he died in 1991. John's own politics reflected his father's leftist leanings. His mother Helene perished in an apartment fire in February, 2003. A product of New York City public schools, Dr. Montana graduated from Harpur College (SUNY Binghamton) in 1969 where he majored in Science and Mathematics. He taught junior high school in Newark, New Jersey for two years before attending medical school. Dr. Montana graduated New York Medical College, Valhalla in 1975. After working at Cabrini-Stuyvesant Polyclinic, he opened his internal medicine practice in 1984. He was an attending physician at Cabrini Medical Center until it closed. Then he attended at St. Vincent's Hospital. Dr. Montana's illness caused him to close his medical practice in mid-December, 2007. The AIDS epidemic motivated him to focus his practice on treating AIDS-related opportunistic infections and cancers--which signaled fatality in less than two years at the beginning of the epidemic. His beloved partner, Jimmie Jackson, died from AIDS early on, and his death both devastated and deeply politicized John to continue the fight against AIDS. A firm proponent of safer-sex, Dr. Montana advised the Gay Men's Health Crisis (GMHC) on medical issues from its inception. He lectured on AIDS to community and professional groups throughout the city and was politically involved in ACT-UP and other AIDS-related organizations. John gave generously of his time and money to many gay community organizations including Senior Action in a Gay Environment (SAGE) and the Callen-Lorde Community Health Center. Until the end of his life, he maintained his conviction that the right-wing-dominated, federal government covertly propagated the epidemic, if not intentionally, then by intentional negligence--the ultimate goal being the elimination of the gay community. A gay-civil-rights activist and life-long Democrat, he was horrified at the response of the Reagan and Bush presidencies to AIDS and gay rights issues in general. He became inconsolable when his long-term partner, Daniel C., was deported from this country in 1999. Being bi-lingual, John was a benefactor to many in New York's Latino communities, and especially to Daniel's family. Dr. Montana often visited South America where he was a benefactor to small villages helping poor people at local medical clinics. Dr. Montana was a patron of the arts whether for museum-sponsored projects or for individual, fledgling, gay artists including E. J. Weiss, Ferron Bell and William Schwedler. He especially appreciated the works of Charles Demuth. John loved New York City, but enjoyed traveling throughout Europe and South America. John had many patients and friends in diplomatic positions who hosted him in Brazil, Italy, France, and Spain. Recently he traveled to Turkey, and only two weeks before his death, he returned from a cruise to Venice and Greece with two friends who made his trip as comfortable as possible. He fell critically ill upon his return. John Montana is survived by his brother Victor and his nephew John, both of New Hampshire. He is deeply mourned by his cousins Vicki De Bruin-Tarlow, Carol Daniels, Jesse Kamras, and also by his close friends John Helmuth, Ron Illardo, Philip Kayal, Jim D'Eramo, Patrick Hacker, Joe Nicholson and Angel, who with others, nursed him daily near the end. He is also mourned by his extended family in Finland and Israel, and by his friends throughout the world, but most particularly by the New York City gay community that he shepherded courageously through the AIDS epidemic--Dr. John Montana was an AIDS hero. Dr. Montana's Memorial Service will be Sunday, November 23 at 3:30pm in the Auditorium (10th Floor) of St. Vincents Hospital, 170 West 12th Street, Greenwich Village. Family and friends are welcome. Any questions should be directed to Philip Kayal: pkayal@comcast.net.

headline: Arts, Briefly; PBS-Affiliated Channel Is Criticized, Again

The new host on ''The Good Night Show,'' Michele Lepe, plays an undercover policewoman who poses as a prostitute in a short independent picture, ''Jamaica Motel.'' Last summer the channel fired the original host, Melanie Martinez, because seven years ago she acted in videos spoofing public service announcements advocating sexual abstinence. Sprout, a joint venture of the Public Broadcasting System, Comcast, Hit Entertainment and Sesame Workshop, said at the time that Ms. Martinez's earlier role might ''undermine her character's credibility with our audience.'' A parenting blog, the Zero Boss, accused Sprout of ''hypocrisy'' for hiring Ms. Lepe after firing Ms. Martinez. PBS's ombudsman, Michael Getler, wrote in recent columns that he had received complaints from viewers, and that while he hadn't seen ''Jamaica Motel,'' Sprout's ''decision-making here looks to me to be inconsistent.'' Sandy Wax, the president of the channel, said in a statement that ''prior to hiring Michele, we were given full disclosure of all her acting credits.'' ELIZABETH JENSEN

[C1.] VIDEO ON THE XBOX -- Microsoft said that it would offer movies and episodes of television shows for download to its Xbox 360 game consoles, beginning Nov. 22. [C1.] CHINA TO PASS U.S. AS POLLUTER -- Nearly a decade ahead of previous projections, China will surpass the United States in 2009 as the biggest emitter of the main gas linked to global warming, the International Energy Agency has concluded. headline: Finding Profits When Times Are Tough
summary: THE problem with doing something well is that people expect you to do even better next time. Corporate profit margins -- earnings as a percentage of revenues -- have been running at close to all-time highs, but they can improve only so much. High margins in any industry are an invitation for fresh competitors to enter the marketplace and skim some of the cream. That puts a ceiling on margins in the best of times, and as the slowing of economic output in the first quarter showed, these are not the best of times.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
summary: GOOGLE, STILL FEELING LUCKY -- Google's shares closed up $14.60 at $509.65, rising past the $500 mark for the first time, not bad for a company that was forced to reduce its initial share price to $85 barely two years ago because of lackluster demand. And an analyst who once recommended selling at $137 is among those predicting that it will rise to $600 within a year. [Page C1.] A LINE IN THE SAND -- Rupert Murdoch has pushed the boundaries throughout his career, usually without contrition. But the media billionaire's decision to cancel a TV and book project featuring O. J. Simpson by subsidiaries of the News Corporation was a rare demonstration that even Mr. Murdoch has his limits. [C1.] RIGHTS TO SIMPSON BOOK SOUGHT -- Seeking to prevent a canceled book and television interview with O. J. Simpson from ever becoming public, the family of Ronald L. Goldman, who was murdered along with Nicole Brown Simpson in 1994, has asked the News Corporation to turn over the rights to the material. [C5.] INVESTORS SHOW FAITH IN DELL -- Dell reported another quarter of slow revenue growth and falling profits, compared to year-earlier results. But investors looked at the marked improvement from the previous quarter as a sign of a turnaround and pushed the company's stock up in after-hours trading. [C1.] SENATOR AT THE CROSSROADS -- As Senator Christopher Dodd prepares to take over the leadership of the Senate Banking Committee while also considering a run for the presidency, lobbyists and lawmakers are all asking the same question. Will he be a populist champion for the middle class or will he advance the causes of corporate patrons? [C1.] ASIAN GIANTS SEEK CLOSER TIES -- India and China established a 10-point strategy to strengthen economic relations as President Hu Jintao of China, left, started a four-day visit to India. As he and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India came face to face, there was evidence that they were trying to define the Asian version of globalization. [C2.] SHORT-LIVED SOFTWARE CEASE-FIRE -- Less than three weeks after they reached an accord hailed as proof that open source and proprietary software companies could work together, Novell and Microsoft executives are bickering in public. [C4.] POTATO TODAY, GONE TOMORROW -- The United States Potato Board is joining the ranks of marketers using a technique known as pop-up retailing, opening a temporary store that consumers can visit for a short time. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C4.] LENS CLEANER RECALLED -- Advanced Medical Optics has recalled 2.9 million bottles of Complete MoisturePlus contact lens solution after harmful bacteria were found in some units sold in Japan. The company's shares fell 8.9 percent, and the company issued lowered forecasts for sales and earnings through 2007. The voluntary recall is a precaution against eye infections caused by water-borne bacteria that infiltrated a plant in China; no problems have been reported in the United States. [C6.] COMCAST AND DISNEY IN DEAL -- The Comcast Corporation and the Walt Disney Company have signed a multibillion-dollar distribution deal that allows the cable operator to distribute Disney content through its video-on-demand service. [C10.] G.M. SCUTTLES SATURN MINIVAN -- General Motors confirmed that it had decided not to build a Saturn minivan that was tentatively planned for production at its Spring Hill, Tenn., plant, but the company said that it would find a new vehicle for workers there to build. Union leaders said they feared the plant, where the first Saturn was built, would close. [C4.] PENTAGON SEEKS SUPERCOMPUTER -- The Pentagon awarded almost $500 million in contracts to I.B.M. and Cray Inc. to design a supercomputer several times as fast as today's most powerful systems. [C8.] AVIATION COMPANY RISES IN DEBUT -- Shares of Spirit AeroSystems Holdings, a unit of Onex, the Canadian leveraged buyout company, rose 12 percent in their first day of trading in New York yesterday. Onex formed Spirit in June 2005 after acquiring Boeing's aircraft component factories in Wichita, Kan., and Tulsa and McAlester, Okla. Spirit stock opened at $26 and ended the day's trading at $29 a share. [C8] STOCKS RISE WITH OIL PRICES -- Stocks resumed their November advance yesterday after an increase in oil prices lifted the Exxon Mobil Corporation, the world's biggest energy company, and shares of Google surpassed $500 for the first time. [C8.] Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. headline: The Big Ten Wins...Sort Of
summary: When last we left the new Big Ten Network -- in a column I wrote last October -- the new all-Big-Ten-sports-all-the-time network was in a long struggle to gain carriage with the big cable companies, starting with Comcast, Time Warner and Charter Communications. The cable guys were outraged because the Big Ten wanted a dollar per subscriber per month -- nearly triple the price commanded by, say, CNN or the USA Network -- and was further demanding a primo spot on extended basic, which is where everybody who starts a network wants to be. For their part, the cable companies wanted to relegate the Big Ten Network to a sports tier, where the fans who watched the games would also be the ones who pay for them. For the record, while I do not believe in a la carte cable pricing, I do think that sports should be treated as an exception: sports channels are so expensive -- ESPN alone is some $3 a month a subscriber -- that it is the single biggest reason your cable bill is so high. Putting sports channels on a sports tier makes sense, it seems to me.
